questions.question_text_1:
Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions.  
Gregor summoned all his courage to try to bring him back; the manager must have suspected something of the sort, for he leaped several steps at a single bound and disappeared with a cry of, “Huh!” which resounded in the hollow of the stairwell. This flight had the unfortunate effect of causing Gregor’s father—who till now had remained master of himself—to lose his head completely; instead of running after the manager, or at least not interfering with Gregor in his pursuit, he seized in his right hand the manager’s walking stick, which had been left behind on a chair with his overcoat and hat, took up in his left a newspaper from the table, and began stamping his feet and brandishing the newspaper and the cane to drive Gregor back into his room. Gregor’s prayers were unavailing, were not even understood; he had turned to his father a supplicating head, but, meek though he showed himself, his father merely stamped all the louder. In the dining room, despite the cold, the mother had opened the window wide and was leaning out as far as possible, pressing her face in her hands. A great rush of air swept the space between the room and the stairway; the curtains billowed, the papers rustled, and a few sheets flew over the carpet. But the father pursued Gregor pitilessly, whistling and whooping like a savage, and Gregor, who was not used to walking backward, progressed but slowly.  
Had he been able to turn around he could have reached his room quickly, but he feared to make his father impatient by the slowness of his turning and feared also that at any moment he might receive a mortal blow on his head or on his back from this menacing stick. Soon Gregor had no choice; for he realized with terror that when he was going backward he was not master of his direction and, still fearfully watching the attitude of his father out of the corner of his eye, he began his turning movement as quickly as possible, which was really only very slowly. Perhaps his father realized his good intention for, instead of hindering this move, he guided him from a little distance away, helping Gregor with the tip of the stick. If only he had left off that insupportable whistling! Gregor was completely losing his head.  
(Metamorphosis ~ Franz Kafka)

Had he been able to turn around he could have reached his room quickly, but he feared to make his father impatient by the slowness of his turning and feared also that at any moment he might receive a mortal blow on his head or on his back from this menacing stick. Soon Gregor had no choice; for he realized with terror that when he was going backward he was not master of his direction and, still fearfully watching the attitude of his father out of the corner of his eye, he began his turning movement as quickly as possible, which was really only very slowly. Perhaps his father realized his good intention for, instead of hindering this move, he guided him from a little distance away, helping Gregor with the tip of the stick. If only he had left off that insupportable whistling! Gregor was completely losing his head.  
(Metamorphosis ~ Franz Kafka)

questions.question_text_1:
More Than 157 Million Indians Bought 943 Million Movie Tickets in 2023 
More than 157 million Indians watched at least one film in the theatre in 2023. This theatre-going population [1] _____ over the 122 million in 2022. More importantly, it is an 8 percent growth from the pre-pandemic (January to March 2020) [2] _____. [3] _____ bought 943 million tickets. That means they saw [4] _____ films in the year. That number changes depending on the language.  Telugu-speaking audiences are [5] _____; they beat the average with over 9 films a year. Tamil comes [i] _____ and Punjabi is at number three with an average of 5 films a year. Hindi lags with an average of 3. These among others are some of the findings of ‘Sizing the Cinema: 2024,’ a report from Mumbai-based analytics firm Ormax Media. In its third year of publication, the report is based on research conducted in January 2024 [ii] _____ across urban and rural India.  The last Indian Readership Survey in 2019 puts the theatre-going audience at 33 million, so this seems like a large jump. Can a sample-based report be accurate?  Shailesh Kapoor, founder and CEO, Ormax Media, points to the only available metrics– the actual ticket sales (943 million) and box-office revenue (Rs. 12,226 crore). The report is totally [iii] _____ and has been so for three years, he says. Note that the films earned a total revenue of Rs. 19,700 crore in 2023– this includes domestic and overseas theatrical, music, TV and streaming rights. Analysts point out that television is watched regularly by 900 million people. More than 510 million people surf the net daily for videos and films. If anything, the reach numbers for cinema seem low for a film-crazy country with [iv] _____.  “It (the reach of cinema) is only 11 percent of the country’s population,” says Kapoor. Note that the reach number will be way higher if you factor in that [v] _____ spent watching TV is spent on film or that a large proportion of OTT viewing is cinema. These are not factored in by the Ormax report. Even without that, the rise in the overall numbers is impressive, say analysts. 
Excerpted from: Kohli-Khandekar, Vanita. “More Than 157 Million Indians Bought 943 Million Movie Tickets in 2023.” Business Standard, Mumbai, 24 Apr 2024, p. 2. 
Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

More importantly, it is an 8 percent growth from the pre-pandemic (January to March 2020) [2] _____. [3] _____ bought 943 million tickets. That means they saw [4] _____ films in the year. That number changes depending on the language.  Telugu-speaking audiences are [5] _____; they beat the average with over 9 films a year. Tamil comes [i] _____ and Punjabi is at number three with an average of 5 films a year. Hindi lags with an average of 3. These among others are some of the findings of ‘Sizing the Cinema: 2024,’ a report from Mumbai-based analytics firm Ormax Media. In its third year of publication, the report is based on research conducted in January 2024 [ii] _____ across urban and rural India.  The last Indian Readership Survey in 2019 puts the theatre-going audience at 33 million, so this seems like a large jump. Can a sample-based report be accurate?  Shailesh Kapoor, founder and CEO, Ormax Media, points to the only available metrics– the actual ticket sales (943 million) and box-office revenue (Rs. 12,226 crore). The report is totally [iii] _____ and has been so for three years, he says. Note that the films earned a total revenue of Rs. 19,700 crore in 2023– this includes domestic and overseas theatrical, music, TV and streaming rights. Analysts point out that television is watched regularly by 900 million people. More than 510 million people surf the net daily for videos and films. If anything, the reach numbers for cinema seem low for a film-crazy country with [iv] _____.  “It (the reach of cinema) is only 11 percent of the country’s population,” says Kapoor. Note that the reach number will be way higher if you factor in that [v] _____ spent watching TV is spent on film or that a large proportion of OTT viewing is cinema. These are not factored in by the Ormax report. Even without that, the rise in the overall numbers is impressive, say analysts. 
Excerpted from: Kohli-Khandekar, Vanita. “More Than 157 Million Indians Bought 943 Million Movie Tickets in 2023.” Business Standard, Mumbai, 24 Apr 2024, p. 2.

questions.question_text_1:
Fill in the blanks with correct expressions of numbers/values/quantity.

Banned betting sites are piggybacking on popular platforms again, as India’s taxmen and regulators play whack-a-mole with shady operators from distant shores. Betting ads have popped up on grocery app Zepto and on taxis operated by an Uber fleet provider, while items branded 1xBat, a mirror name for betting app 1xBet, sell on Amazon.  India has banned and blocked [i] _____ of offshore gambling platforms, but many of them still operate through so-called mirror sites– replicas of the original with a near identical URL, and hosted on a different server. Meanwhile, [ii] _____ celebrities endorse and keep the betting platforms in public view, while tax authorities stare at lost revenue.  Everest fleet, Uber’s [iii] _____ cab-provider, said it became aware of the ads recently and takes the matter seriously. In September, Uber had invested [iv] $30 _____ in the company. The Zepto app has displayed ads from Parimatch, a banned betting platform. Amazon displays various sports goods branded 1xBat, a close imitation of 1xBet. Despite the government’s blocking them, Cyprus-based 1xBet and Parimatch and Curacao-based Fairplay remain [v] _____ visible through digital advertising, while escaping the tax payments that local gaming companies are subjected to. 
Sadashi, Sakshi. “Betting Ads Mushroom in India’s Regulatory Grey Zone.” Mint, Mumbai, vol. 8, no. 91, 15 Apr. 2025, p. 1. 
Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, and principles** for the **"English II (Computer-Based Exam)"** paper, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships. --- ### **Core Topics & Concepts** The exam covers **4 broad areas**: 1. **Reading Comprehension** (Literary & Non-Literary Passages) 2. **Grammar & Syntax** (Voice, Tense, Modals, Clauses, etc.) 3. **Vocabulary & Word Formation** (Prefixes, Suffixes, Acronyms, Synonyms/Antonyms) 4. **Professional & Social Communication** (Emails, Formal/Informal Language, Politeness) --- --- ### **1. Reading Comprehension** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Literary Passages** (e.g., *Metamorphosis* by Kafka): - **Themes**: Alienation, family dynamics, transformation. - **Character Analysis**: Gregor’s helplessness, father’s aggression. - **Literary Devices**: Imagery (e.g., "whistling like a savage"), symbolism (e.g., the walking stick as power). - **Inference**: Drawing conclusions from actions (e.g., Gregor’s fear of his father). - **Non-Literary Passages** (e.g., news articles, reports): - **Data Interpretation**: Numbers, percentages, comparisons (e.g., "157 million Indians bought 943 million tickets"). - **Cause-Effect**: Why betting sites persist despite bans (mirror sites, celebrity endorsements). - **Tone & Purpose**: Objective (reports) vs. subjective (opinions). #### **Common Question Types:** - Synonyms/Antonyms (e.g., "unfortunate" → "unlucky"; "supplicating" → "demanding"). - Inference (e.g., "Why did Gregor turn around?" → "He lost control backward"). - Detail-based (e.g., "How did the open window affect the room?" → "Caused a rush of air"). --- ### **2. Grammar & Syntax** #### **Key Rules & Examples:** | **Topic** | **Concept** | **Example** | |-------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------| | **Voice (Active/Passive)** | Subject vs. object focus. | Active: *Sandip broke the cup.*
Passive: *The cup was broken by Sandip.* | | **Tense** | Past Perfect: Action completed before another past action. | *The train **had left** by the time I arrived.* | | **Modals** | Obligation (`shall`), ability (`can`), past habit (`would`), polite requests (`could`). | *You **shall** sign the register.* (obligation) | | **Conditionals** | Mixed conditional: Unreal past + unreal future. | *If I **were** you, I **would have invested**.* | | **Clauses** | Adjectival (describes noun), Adverbial (modifies verb), Noun (acts as noun). | *The house **where we live** has trees.* (adjectival) | | **Question Tags** | Match auxiliary verb to subject. | *Let’s go, **shall we**?* | | **Punctuation** | Commas for direct address. | *"Madam Prime Minister**, please..." | | **Degree Adverbs** | Intensify adjectives/verbs (`really`, `much`). | *She **really** must tell.* | | **Viewpoint Adverbs** | Express manner/method (`genetically`, `legally`). | *The fungus was **genetically** engineered.* | --- ### **3. Vocabulary & Word Formation** #### **Key Areas:** - **Prefixes/Suffixes**: - `Re-` (again) → *revolve*. - `Anti-` (against) → *antibody*. - `Carcino-` (cancer) → *carcinogen*. - `-pathy` (disease) → *sympathy*. - **Clipping**: - Back-clipping: *gym* (gymnasium). - Fore-clipping: *flu* (influenza). - **Acronyms**: - New media: *ROFL* (Rolling On Floor Laughing), *HBD* (Happy Birthday). - Traditional: *Ltd.* (Limited) → **Not** a new media acronym. #### **Synonyms/Antonyms:** | **Word** | **Synonym** | **Antonym** | |-----------------|-------------------|------------------| | Unfortunate | Unlucky | Fortunate | | Supplicating | Begging | Demanding | | Pitilessly | Mercilessly | Compassionately | --- ### **4. Professional & Social Communication** #### **Emails:** - **Structure**: - **Salutation**: *Dear [Name]* (formal), *Hi [Name]* (informal). - **Subject Line**: Clear and concise (e.g., *Appointment Confirmation*). - **Sign-off**: *Best regards* (formal), *Talk soon* (informal). - **Mandatory Fields**: Subject, recipient, body. #### **Politeness in Social Contexts:** | **Scenario** | **Appropriate Language** | **Inappropriate Language** | |----------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | **Reminding a colleague** | *"Are you on course to finish the report? Let me know if you need help."* | *"Aren’t you being too lazy about this?"* | | **Inviting to a party** | *"Hi, I’m having a party tonight. Will you be free to drop by?"* | *"Hey, got a party. Mind dropping by?"* (too casual) | | **Refusing food** | *"Thank you, but I have allergies to ghee-based sweets."* | *"Sweets are for lazy sloths."* | | **Requesting help** | *"Could you please review this FIR?"* | *"Fix this man."* (demanding) | --- --- ### **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs** #### **1.
